title: Segmenting Atomic Layers in Images of Atomically Resolved van der Waals Bilayers
content: Over the past decade, van der Waals bilayers (vdWBs) have drawn much attention for their unique, and often tunable, quantum properties. In particular, twisted vdWBs (TvdWBs) hold promise for creating elusive states of matter and for studying the strongly correlated physics that emerge [1]. First principles calculations show that the moiré lattices created by twisting two monolayers of graphene or transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) is more than an optical illusion – the in-plane modulation of electronic and topological structures changes material properties and creates a superlattice which can often be electrically tuned, or strain tuned to produce a variety of states from perfect arrays of quantum emitters to excitonic superlattices with giant spin-orbit coupling [2]. Excitingly, experimental research is largely confirming these findings, like in the case of “magic twist angles” in graphene leading to unconventional superconductivity [3]. As this field develops, experimentalists are realizing that strain and defect engineering can have a significant effect on TvdWBs properties [4].
